Excellent points.

The problem is the Republicans still have a hold on power in Washington, DC, thanks to the gerrymandering of House districts. More people, nationwide, voted for Democrats for Congress in 2012, but the Republicans "won" because the Republican control of state legislatures allowed them to draw House districts where Republican votes were concentrated and Democrat's votes were dispersed. This narrow hold on power, combined with the phony filibuster rules in the Senate, gives the Republicans a partial veto over legislation. Combined with the rise of thousands of right wing talk radio stations, right wing only websites and the clear distortion offered as news by the Fox News channel, and we are in deep do do, to use an expression George Bush the first seemed to like. RItuparno Ghosh was a very interesting man. One of the few successful men in the public eye, he was open about his sexuality and was a cross dresser in public. His manner was very feminine and he was in the process of becoming a woman medically when he passed away. He won 12 national awards for film making and script writing and had a highly successful chat show. He was the first of the new wave film makers in India, making movies that were off beat yet running successfully in the multiplexes. Before new wave Bollywood he brought middle class Bengali audiences to the multiplexes for off beat films. Perhaps showing Bollywood that an audience for such films exists. He also is someone who worked entirely in the vernacular, Bengali, and was able to show that  culture can be more progressive than bourgeois, neo English speaking, Hindutwa supporting urban mass culture. In some ways he was a unique product of middle class Kolkata, known for being economically depressed with a strong, radical, literary, leftist tradition, often described as pseudo-intellectual by the rest of the country. His movies charted the inner world of middle class women with great sensitivity. Though my favorite was Shubhamaharat, a gritty, funny, profane interpretation of Agatha Christie's Mirror Crackd' based in the Kolkata movie industry. His last three movies had gay themes and he acted as a queer man/ transgender in them as well.  Try doing some research on him, you would be surprised.

Janice, I am sorry you were offended by this column. I see the doctor’s recognition of Hospice as a valuable acknowledgement of great institution. My wife spent her last three days at an Annapolis, MD hospice. When they called me to tell me of her death, I spent twenty minute sitting beside her thanking God for the wonderful last resort Hospice offered. Hospice will be better off for this doctor’s acknowledgement.

I think your defense of hospice is powerful and necessary. Still, I felt like the point of Reisman's essay was to show how her own fears and anxiety had kept her from discovering just your point, that there can be life, love, beauty, relationships even at the end of life, but that her perspective changed when she finally faced her fears and walked into the facility.

I found Dr. R's essay very sensitive, very personally searching, and more honestly expressed than we might even say to ourselves. I know the Hospice she writes about, have had a number of friends end their lives there, and like Dr R, I have dreaded the thought of visiting  there or being in residence. My location in AK has protected me from my fears, but her description of warmth and comfort have been told me repeatedly by close friends. What a wonderful person, what a sensitive physician must Dr R be.

I am a hospice nurse. The former hospice that I worked for had three hospice residences.

You stated, "Inpatient hospice is for the truly terminally ill, those just a stone’s throw from rigor mortis. The hospice doctors won’t admit patients unless they have no more than a few days, or at most a few weeks."

This is Not True and I found myself a bit offended by your column.

First of all, I find your comment about 'rigor mortis' to be in poor taste. Secondly, although the patients most certainly are terminally ill, they do not have to be at death's door. Many times there is simply no one to take care of them in the home. Or they live alone. In residential hospice they can stay for many days or weeks, we even had some patients stay months. Some come just for respite care. It is not a place for doom and gloom. They feel secure and have many volunteers and nurse who visit them. They can decorate their rooms as they please and they can have visitors whenever they want to have them come. There is usually a sitting room or porch or patio. They can have their pets visit. Their family can bring any food that they may like and store it in the kitchen. There is music. Many times you hear laughter. People who are dying do not feel isolated, alone and frightened. It is a sad place for sure, but much better than you describe.

"But what question did Silver intend for these arguments to answer?"

Why, the question the article poses, you dunce: Why Canadian teams haven't won a Stanley Cup in over two decades.

The argument Nate makes is pretty straightforward. Canadian teams have underachieved in the NHL postseason for a few reasons:

-There are fewer Canadian tearms in the NHL than there probably should be, making the odds of one winning the Cup lower.
-The Canadian teams that currently exist are not, like their American counterparts, economically motivated to put a winning team on the ice every season.
-Canadian teams were hampered by an unfavorable exchange rate and, later, by a hard salary cap.
-Plain old bad luck.

Janice,  Tylenol and acetaminophen are exactly the same thing.  Wake up.

tylenol and acetominophen are exactly the same drug.
ibuprophen and advil are exactly the same drug.
ibuprophen (advil/motrin), naproxen, nuprin, etc. are all NSAIDS.

tylenol is a pain reliever but not anti-inflammatory so usually not good for arthritis
advil/motrin (NSAID--non steroidal anti inflammatory drug) is a pain reliever and anti inflammatory and therefore better for arthritis
aspirin is a pain reliever and anti inflammatory but not NSAID
there are many NSAIDS which are not over the counter (prescription drugs)

all drugs have side effects and therefore are potentially dangerous

see your doctor
please excuse spelling errors

I think much of today's middle class dissatisfaction comes from the constant harping of how much more the wealthy have than the middle and working classes. It promotes envy, a self-eating characteristic. Why should I truly care if some pople live in 60,000 sqr foot houses if I have a house if my own? If we define "success" by how many expensive toys we own, many, many middle class families have lots of them - more than their grandparents could have ever imagined. Big screen TV's are not just for the rich -heck, they sell like hot cakes at the PX on military bases - hardly the shopping place of the rich. It's a rare middle class family that doesn't have air conditioning. Heck, even my cleaning woman and yard man have cell phones as do their grandchildren; mine do not.

We need to get over the idea tht if you have more than I do, then you took mine. I know a man who graduated from a technical high school and he thinks that the president of a Fortune 500 company has no right to make more than he does and that it is their fault that he doesn't. Huh?

Envy wasn't named one of the Seven Deadly Sins for nothing. We need to move beyond that and this newspaper needs to quit feeding it on a daily basis.

"Another decade, another Gatsby. The actors change but the message put forward in the adaptations of F. Scott Fitzgerald’s 1925 book stays the same. The 1920s were as ephemeral as a Champagne bubble. A fake stock market, an illicit liquor business and other falsehoods made Jay Gatsby and others like him into correspondingly false millionaires. The pleasure of the rich, “careless people,” as a character calls them, came at a cost to the rest, especially the middle class, the small people, mere ants in black tie to be trampled by giants like Gatsby at their parties."
Well, if the book in question was a nonfictional analysis of the effects of income inequality in the 1920s, you *might* be on to something. But it is a *novel,* a work of fiction. And the movie about whose details you are so critical, is not even a first rate adaptation of that novel, which puts you yet another degree away from reality. This is the problem with the modern Republican movement: actual truth and facts are *always* secondary to the preferred narrative, and it is what makes this essay essentially worthless.
Analogies anyone?

The fact of national alcohol prohibition had unsen effects on the econmy. While destroying a good 20% of the legally taxable economy, prohibition allowed for numerous otherwise unemployed or many smart people to enter legitimate business through the eventual repeal of the Halstead act. What few know now was that just before prohibition want belly up in '32-'33, the GOP and Christian religious nuts like the Anti Saloon League, and Womens Christian Temperance Union had gotten the congress to pass some of the most vicious, cruel "Sharia style" anti alcohol laws designed to put children and mothers as well as bootleggers, drinkers and tipplers all into state and federal prisons for 10 years or often 20 or 30. Angry agents of failed prohibition had decided in the last years to get mean and to punish people because they drank and not for selling liquor.
Had the law not been repealed, prohibition would have been America's firt big experience with a stupid, vengeful drug law which one portion of the country insisted on forcing on the other. We missed it by a whisker. Thus many got starts in legit, licensed liquor business's after prohibition.

With the "Blogosphere"  replacing traditional news sources W.A. Spitzer has a valid point.  How does one identify a "true" reporter?  If I write to occasional article for the Washington Post am I a "reporter"?   If I run a blog to support an alien being who is the representative of the one true goddess, am I a reporter?  I think we need to define who is a reported before we begin giving them blanket freedoms.  Heaven knows what truths that reporter might share with the one true goddess.  Or what hidden secret the goddess might have that should be kept secret.
Perhaps you should revisit the 5th. Amendment as well...

W.A. Spitzer has raised the question that makes so many of my journalist friends squirm. Whenever I ask them, "Who's a journalist?" they are only certain that, of course, they are.
Here's an analogy I use: The humorist Dave Barry writes for The Miami Herald, and he has won a Pulitzer prize. Surely, no one disputes that Dave Barry is a journalist. So...what about Jon Stewart? Mr. Stewart is also a humorist. To be sure, his commentaries are delivered on television, but they are also much more politically pointed than Barry's. I assume, then, that Jon Stewart is a journalist. And so we come to Stephen Colbert...but you see my point. Give me a definition of "journalist" that will protect Dave Barry but not Jon Stewart....

Should there be a law that exempts reporters from the civic duty to give evidence? It is all very nice for members of the "press" to become holier than tho and claim that they have some sort of special exemption granted by the first amendment, but I think there is the potential for some major problems. Who is a reporter? Someone who works for a newspaper, someone who publishes a blog on the internet, someone who sends a letter or e-mail to several friends? Right now I am typing a comment that may well be published by the NYT; does that make me a reporter and do I therefore have some special exemption? Why not? Why can't everyone claim to be a reporter, and why can't I claim that any and all information I have in my possession I intend to publish at some point in the future? We know who doctors and lawyers are because they have received degrees by a "qualified" institution and passed exams, but it seems to me that just about anyone who claims to be a reporter, has to be granted the status of a reporter.

I worked off the theory that teen years were more my problem than theirs. After all one has to deal with the burgeoning sexuality of what was, not so long ago your innocent little baby. Then you have to cope with they're leaving home. Yeah I know that was the plan but somehow I want to reel it all back. Not exactly start over but do more with them. Do more for them. Then you think of them becoming adults and you think "Dear God please don't let me have raised a criminal!"  We've all read different scenarios where I'm sure the parents thought they were on the right track but something came out of left(insofar as you're concerned!) and sent them down the wrong path! You know they are going to try all the crazy stuff you did plus dream up something of their own.  Teen years are hell but let's not put the onus all on the kids. We are just plain worried sick that we screwed up. It will be at least 20 years before you truly find out. I was lucky to have good kids.

When the USSR fell apart; what were our surprised spys doing? They were living the good life and to maintain it they insured "just" enough info got back home.
That is what they were doing! It's not tough to figure that out.

Accidentally, carelessly?? And you say you saw the video? I don't understand.

The American pilots ruthlessly and deliberately killed innocent Iraqis, including people coming to help those they had shot from their helicopter and two children.

And they laughed while they were doing this, like it was a video game!

Bradley Manning was a person of conscience. It was horrors like this secret video that inspired the young soldier to release the documents to Wikileaks. As he said in court, he did what he did because he thought the American people needed to know what was actually going on in their name. He knew he was risking his future, but he did it anyway.

To me, Bradley Manning is a hero. The government claims he put American lives at risk. This is a lie. What he really did was embarrass U.S. officials, and that's why they'd really like to put him to death if they could get away with it. That's why they tortured him and kept him in solitary confinement for months.

From the content of most of these letters, I can only conclude that, after decades of bad reporting and journalists courting those in power, people have turned against the Fourth Estate.

This is extremely dangerous. Often the only defenses we the people have against bad and oppressive governments are brave and relentless reporters, and those willing to leak to them the truth about what the people in power are doing secretly.

The news that the US has spies is not news. We have spies in North Korea? Who's surprised - the North Koreans? Same goes for al Qaeda.

The value of espionage is overrated. When the USSR fell apart apparently our spies were surprised. What were they doing all that time?

Bradley Manning is going on trial this week, after a long long period of being basically tortured with many months of draconian solitary confinement. And what information did he make public that endangered our national security? The release of video showing an American helicopter accidentally (carelessly?) shooting some reporters in a Baghdad street. When I saw it I thought I had already seen it before. Certainly incidents like that had been widely reported. Did this change the course of the war in Iraq? Certainly not fast enough to keep us from making more mistakes and causing more mayhem and destruction.

We are supposed to be different from countries like the former USSR that tried to control the news.

There's no justification for spying on reporters. Embarrassing officials and exposing bad government policies are not a crime.

We've been having a national breakdown over the 2nd amendment. What about the 1st? "Congress shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion, or prohibiting the free exercise thereof; or abridging THE FREEDOM OF SPEECH, or of THE PRESS; or the right of the people peaceably to assemble, and to petition the government for a redress of grievances." (my emphases)
